p: The analysis technique described by Shantha and Decker [ 43] was used for the peroxide value (PV) monitoring. An amount of 0.3 g of oil was taken from each of the oil samples; these were agitated in a vortex until diluted in 3.5 mL of a mix consisting of seven parts chloroform to three parts methanol. A 500 µL aliquot was taken from the resulting blend and added 25 µL of a dissolution containing 0.144 M of FeSO 4-7H 2O and BaCl 2 in HCl 0.4 M and 25 µL of NH 4SCN 0.44 M. This solution was agitated afterward and allowed to stand for 10 min in the dark. The absorbance was measured at 500 nm with a Thermo Scientific, Multiskan Spectrum ® spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific) and was compared to a calibration curve which had known concentrations of Fe +3. A higher absorbance means a higher presence of Fe +3, therefore, a higher PV. Additionally, the change of color to red is evidence of a high PV. Peroxide value was expressed as milliequivalents of O 2/kg of sample (meO 2/kg). The entire assay was performed by triplicate.
